summary: Condemned Defense Secretary Hegseth's plan to use Joint Base McGuire-Dix-Lakehurst as a detention site for undocumented immigrants, calling the decision an inappropriate use of military resources and national defense infrastructure; argued it jeopardizes military preparedness, paves the way for ICE raids across New Jersey communities, enables inhumane treatment, and has led to unlawful deportation of U.S. citizens (including children); urged immediate reversal and called on Republican colleagues to join in opposing the action. On July 29, 2025 co-led a letter with Rep. Herb Conaway Jr. and other Members demanding clarification and transparency from Defense and DHS leadership, requesting a prompt briefing and written responses by August 15, 2025 on timeline for operations, facility construction, base operations reimbursement/funding, detainee qualifications and care, and coordination with local authorities. In January 2026 he voted against the DHS funding bill, explicitly tying his opposition to reported ICE abuses (harassment, unconstitutional searches, and a deadly shooting) and insisting DHS must enact meaningful reforms and submit to congressional oversight before receiving additional funds.

Gill introduced the REMAIN in Mexico Act to codify and reinstate President Trump's Migrant Protection Protocols (Remain in Mexico), requiring DHS to apply 2019 guidance. He claims the original policy reduced illegal border crossings and fraudulent asylum claims, blames the Biden administration and Democrats for undoing border protections and creating a surge (including alleging 'over 10 million' illegal entrants), and characterizes the situation as requiring immediate congressional action to secure the border. He also publicly praised President Trump's efforts to 'secure our border' following the President's March 2025 Joint Address. In February 2026 he introduced the Somalia Immigration Moratorium Act, proposing a 25-year moratorium on both immigrant and non-immigrant visas from Somalia to codify prior presidential proclamations. He justified the measure by citing assimilation concerns, high rates of welfare/Medicaid/food stamp use among Somali households, vetting challenges due to weak identity systems in Somalia, and recent fraud incidents, and said the moratorium would protect taxpayers, public safety, and national sovereignty while allowing integration of Somalis already in the U.S.; the bill preserves certain exceptions (existing residents, LPRs, diplomatic visas). In January 2026 he introduced the Student Visa Integrity Act to tighten oversight of the student visa program—expanding in-person interviews, restricting program transfers, setting firm program end dates to reduce overstays, requiring disclosure of institutional ties to the Chinese government, imposing penalties for visa fraud, and barring nationals from designated adversarial countries from studying in the United States—framing these as immigration-enforcement and national-security priorities. In November 2025 he introduced the Expedited Removal of Criminal Aliens Act to expand expedited removal authority to violent criminal aliens, mandate detention and rapid removal for gang members, terrorists, and those convicted of violent crimes, and to make such individuals ineligible for withholding of removal, arguing these steps prevent abuse of asylum protections and remove dangerous foreign nationals more quickly. On October 8, 2025 he publicly announced the House version of that bill (the House companion to Sen. Ashley Moody's S.1827), framed it as closing statutory loopholes that limit expedited removal to recent border crossers within 100 miles and 14 days of entry, and emphasized it would deny withholding of removal to violent criminal aliens to prevent asylum abuse. In March 2025 and again in November 2025 he filed articles of impeachment against Chief Judge James E. Boasberg after the judge blocked President Trump's invocation of the Alien Enemies Act; Gill argued those rulings prevented the deportation of violent foreign gang members (including Tren de Aragua and MS-13) and thereby interfered with immigration enforcement and public safety. In September 2025 he introduced the Domestic Jobs Protection Act to remove the Department of Homeland Security's discretionary authority to issue work permits (Employment Authorization Documents) to unauthorized immigrants and to ensure only visa categories explicitly authorized by Congress can receive work authorization; he framed the bill as preventing future administrations from using discretionary EADs to revive DACA-style programs or expand illegal immigration and as protecting American workers from a 'magnet' of cheap labor. The Domestic Jobs Protection Act received support from hardline immigration groups such as the Immigration Accountability Project, Federation for American Immigration Reform, and the Bull Moose Project and was cosponsored by several conservative House members. In February 2025 he joined House Judiciary Committee Republicans in filing an amicus brief supporting President Trump's executive order on birthright citizenship, arguing the Fourteenth Amendment's 'jurisdiction' language should be read to focus on 'allegiance' and indicating support for narrowing automatic birthright citizenship. He has also tied immigration concerns to election integrity efforts, leading calls for the SAVE Act to require proof of citizenship to register to vote and arguing illegal aliens should be excluded from voting. In June 2025 he introduced the New IDEA Act, which would mandate IRS-DHS-SSA data-sharing to identify and remove unauthorized workers from the workforce, permanently authorize and strengthen E-Verify (including allowing job offers to be contingent on final verification and giving employers legal protection when relying on E-Verify), and close tax-deduction loopholes that he says incentivize hiring illegal aliens—framing these steps as measures to dismantle the 'jobs magnet' driving illegal immigration and to hold employers accountable. In an October 1, 2025 statement he criticized Democrats for demanding 'taxpayer funded handouts for illegal aliens' amid a funding lapse and called such funding a 'nonstarter' for his district. At his January 3, 2025 swearing-in Gill reiterated immediate priorities to 'secure our southern border' and 'deport Biden's illegal aliens,' pledging to make border enforcement an early focus of his term. In July 2025 he voted to pass President Trump's One Big Beautiful Bill, which he praised for securing the border, expanding and accelerating deportations, and closing perceived loopholes that he says have fueled the border crisis. On February 26, 2025 he voted in favor of a House budget resolution to extend President Trump's tax cuts and said the resolution provides the necessary funding for what he described as 'the largest mass deportation campaign in United States history,' signaling his support for using budget measures to finance large-scale deportation operations. On March 11, 2025 Gill voted yes on the House continuing resolution to freeze spending levels and avoid a shutdown, saying the measure would allow Republicans to prioritize President Trump's reconciliation package and enable the administration to carry out mass deportations and other border-enforcement actions. In June 2025 he also introduced the Mobilizing Against Sanctuary Cities Act to block federal financial assistance for one year to cities or states that refuse to honor ICE detainers or restrict communication with DHS, arguing sanctuary jurisdictions that shield illegal aliens should be cut off from federal funding to enforce immigration laws and protect taxpayers.

Criticized DHS and ICE actions during immigration enforcement in Tucson, highlighting alleged excessive force against community members, press, and elected officials and requesting review of immigration enforcement practices and their community impact. Condemned an ICE raid at a longtime local restaurant where she and her staff say they were pushed aside and pepper-sprayed after identifying as congressional staff, calling the agency "lawless" and demanding answers about whether raids target public safety threats or long-standing community members. Also criticized a Border Patrol raid of a humanitarian aid site (No More Deaths) reported to have occurred without a warrant, and has joined calls for accountability for ICE and DHS leadership over deaths in detention and alleged abuses. Cosponsored immigration reform and protections including the American Dream and Promise Act, Protect Vulnerable Immigrant Youth Act, Protecting Sensitive Locations Act, and other bills to limit ICE overreach and protect immigrant communities. Most recently took to the House floor to condemn the Border Patrol entry and arrests at a humanitarian aid camp in southern Arizona, stressed that the Fourth Amendment and due process do not "disappear" in border communities, and declared that humanitarian aid is not a crime. In addition, at a Minneapolis field hearing she called out the killing of Renee Nicole Good by a federal agent, decried the lack of transparency in the federally-controlled probe, labeled ICE a lawless agency, and demanded that Congress not allocate further funds to immigration enforcement until significant reforms are implemented. Has also warned that unilateral U.S. military interventions and regime-change actions abroad increase forced migration and humanitarian need, linking foreign-policy choices to immigration and refugee pressures. Recently voted against a DHS funding bill that she says dramatically expands funding for ICE while stripping oversight offices and failing to require basic safeguards, and she urged the Senate to reject the bill and asserted that ICE must be dismantled. She has explicitly called for rescinding large ICE funding allocations and ending the militarization of cities as part of immigration reform and accountability efforts. Most recently condemned a fatal shooting by an ICE agent in Minneapolis as horrific and deeply troubling, arguing that ICE's presence makes communities less safe and calling for Congress to investigate, hold hearings, and rein in the agency.

Supports construction of President Trump's Border Wall and backed H.R.1 provisions intended to fund that project; voted for the reconciliation bill that his office says builds the wall as part of fulfilling the administration's immigration/security priorities. Co-sponsored the bipartisan Laken Riley Act (H.R.29) and publicly commended its passage; the bill would require ICE to arrest, detain, and remove illegal aliens who commit theft offenses and would give states standing to sue federal officials who fail to enforce immigration law, underscoring a focus on stricter immigration enforcement and removal.
